intro: Arundinella montalbanica, commonly known as the Montalbán reed, is a perennial grass native to parts of Central America and the Caribbean. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in wetland or riparian habitats, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its inflorescence consists of dense, spike-like clusters of small, pale green to brownish flowers. Arundinella montalbanica plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various wildlife species.
